I think a better way to explain this is because of the equivalence of gravitational acceleration and released tension governed by the conservation of momentum. When you hang a slinky like that, you're looking at earth's gravitational potential (9.8 m/s squared) energy for that slinky's weight encoded as a tension across its stretched length. 

The total tension is exactly 9.8 m/s squared - no more no less. A hanging slinky is not uniformly tensed, the most is at the top coils and zero tension is in the bottom coil. The bottom stays frozen after letting go because of the conservation of momentum. The entire slinky system's acceleration could never exceed 9.8, therefore even though the top/middle accelerate extra to gravity to the exact proportion they are tensed, the bottom must exhibit no apparent acceleration for the directing forces (tension + gravitational acceleration) to conserve momentum. If the bottom fell before tension was released, it would be increasing slinky tension which would require extra energy.

Actually the answer "end didn't notice" is untheoretical let me explain why the end of spring remained stationary:
When you hold one part of the spring in your hand and allow the second end to elongate as much as it takes to reach equilibrium both the weight force and spring force will be equal (note that the spring force is -k(L2-L1) or (stiffness) x (elongation)), so the only variable for the spring force is elongation.
To have an equal force to its weight it needs to elongate until delta L times K is exactly equal. Now when you drop the upper part it will be pulled by spring force and weight hitting the other end to create a down force and with the impact of both ends the spring force will reach zero and the weight force will be the only force on the system.
To make things simple think of a spring stretched horizontally on a table with hands holding each side and release one side you will not feel any change in forces in the hand holding the spring until the other side hit causing an impact force.
For the ball question, If you attached weight to the end the weight will make an equilibrium by extending the elongation but if the weight is much more than the spring elongation can handle it can't make an equilibrium thus the spring will move downward before getting together.

Where as what's obviously happening, is that the tension, regardless of how weak or strong it is, is keeping the entire slinky suspended, save for one link, the top most link, which unlike the other links doesn't have tension which is attracted upwards, and because density(something inherent to the slinky, like it's inherent tension, as opposed to the outside force of the earth's supposed 'gravity) dictates that more dense mass displaces less dense mass, the top most link displaces the air between it and the link below it, and then touches (fuses) with the link below it, and since there's no upward distance left for the lower link's tension to try and overcome, it then no longer is in a stasis and goes downwards as well, and then so on and so on. Remember the slinky is a SINGLE object so it can do this, but it's not like a string which is already practically fused. Slinky behaves as a closed system, as a whole. Its center of mass will have a uniform "1g" acceleration towards the ground at all times. The system itself is a different story. it is a self/gravity-loaded system in equilibrium, with a potential for dampened oscillation, to boot. So, the bottom will start falling but not before the deformation wave from the system equalization process reaches in (speed of sound in solids, I think) plus all the non-symetrical, in-system, oscillation-augmented elastic deformation into a relaxed spring state.

You get a different perspective on this if you think about it in terms of Einstein's equivalence principle. According this principle gravity and acceleration are the same thing. When an object is in free fall it is actually in an inertial frame of reference although it seems to be accelerating to us. When the slinky is let go the centre of gravity seems to accelerate downwards and the bottom stays still. It's actually the bottom that is accelerating upwards towards the centre of gravity and the centre of gravity is an an inertial frame of reference. Because the tension on the bottom is the same as when it was dangling it accelerates at g. This appears to us to be stationary because according the principle of equivalence we are constantly accelerating upwards at g.

This is a fascinating phenomenon. A lot of questions suggest themselves. Does it depend on the weight of the slinky? Does it depend on the tension in the slinky? Would it still do this in a weaker or stronger gravitational field, say on the moon? 

Imagine stretching a slinky out in a zero gravity environment then letting it go. It would collapse to the middle of the slinky. If you then did this in a very weak gravitational field, stretching it vertically, it doesn't seem obvious that it would suddenly start collapsing to the bottom. It might be just a coincidence that the Earth's gravitational field is just right for this to happen. Perhaps not, it's not at all obvious. Wow, what a great problem. 

However, the slinky must be collapsing at the exact same rate that objects fall in the Earth's gravitational field. Is it just a coincidence?

Yes! The top falls faster because the forces on it are the force of gravity -mg (as all the slinky has on it) and -T (the force the parts of the slinky have on each other). Therefore a=(-mg-T)m or a=-g -T/m, a more negative acceleration than just g. This also makes sense because the sum of the forces on the bottom must be 0, so for the bottom a=0=-mg+T so T=mg. It gets a little complicated because we're not dealing with halves, but you get the idea.

The simple way to think of this is that each ring of the slinky is experiencing a force towards the adjacent ring. The ring at the bottom is experiencing a force down-wards due to gravity and an upwards force towards the ring above and are in balance. The top ring is experiencing a downward force due to gravity and a downward force from the ring below and are countered by being held. When released, the bottom ring still experiences both forces until the above ring moves, so the slinky cascades.

A Slinky's mas is constant. But, the difference between the top and bottom masses in the video are not. The act of being suspended creates tension due to gravity; the bottom being heavier than the top.  This is potential energy. When the energy is released the forces compete to be in balance. The top portion of the Slinky rushes towards the bottom because the potential energy is far greater than then pull of gravity between bottom and the ground.  Once it becomes equal the Slinky falls to earth.

No, the faster (i.e. more frames per second) something is shot at, the slower it will be (and here is the key) when PLAYED BACK AT NORMAL speed.  By normal speed, we're normally talking somewhere around 30fps (29.97fps NTSC, 25fps PAL, 30/25 and 60/50 fps for HD, etc.)  It is also called "overcranking" because in the old days they used to crank the cameras faster to achieve slowmo.

An additional point of interest that they failed to address in this video regards what would happen if they suddenly stopped the top of the slinky from falling. The bottom would not stay stationary in that case. If you stopped the top from reaching the bottom, the compression wave would carry on and the bottom would drop away from the now stationary top. So there's really no way to cheat this system. It's nature behaving just as we all knew it did, only in a context we don't often witness.

If the setting is the same, i.e. the slinky gets to settle to the tension which counters the gravity, sure it would. Try to understand the physics behind the experiment. Gravity is acting on the bottom end all the time and upward tension is keeping it in place. The bottom drops after the upward tension drops. A tension change on the upper part of the slinky isn't instantly delivered to the bottom: there is a delay.

@SimaanFreeloader Continued: Once the spring finishes compressing, then the compressed spring is pulled to the ground by a combination of momentum from the top of the spring and gravity. Notice that even with the momentum of the top half of the spring "pushing" it downward, the compressed spring still moves much slower that the top half alone.

Actual explanation from reddit:
When a stretched spring is unrestrained, both ends of the spring are pulled towards the spring's center.So what you are seeing is a 2 forces (tension and gravity) acting on the two ends of the spring with two different results:
The top of the slinky accelerates downward very quickly due to the combined force of gravity and tension The bottom of the slinky stays approximately still because the downward force of gravity is balanced out by the upward force of tension
